 REPUBLIC OF ARMENIA ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND Country Background 1.1. Armenia is a landlocked country of 3.7 million people bordered by Azerbaijan, Georgia, Iran and Turkey. It declared its independence formally on September 23, 1991. The Government of President Ter-Petrossian, which has been in power since that time, has been able to create a level of continuity essential to recovery. With few natural resources, Armenia depends for its economic growth on its highly educated population and strong entrepreneurial traditions. While regional political tensions are gradually easing, current economic prospects remain constrained by the legacy of Soviet central planning. Production has been highly dependent on trade with the rest of the Former Soviet Union (FSU) (exports and imports represented over 50% of GDP during the 1980s) and on industry (which constituted about 60% of Net Material Product). In the absence of raw materials and primary processing facilities, Armenia has had to rely heavily on imports of semi-finished goods and critical inputs into domestic industry, particularly of primary energy resources. Armenia was also the location of a disproportionate share of the Soviet military-industrial complex. This high degree of integration into the FSU economy induced economic collapse in Armenia when the intra-FSU trade, payments and financial system broke down. More fundamentally, the elimination of non-market pricing in trade between FSU states imposed a severe terms of trade shock on Armenia, particularly due to the sharp rise in energy import prices. The lack of comparative advantage of significant parts of Armenia's productive base was exposed. 1.2. Progress on reorienting government in the transition to the market economy has accelerated with the improvement in the regional political situation. There have been several recent positive developments in Armenia's relations with its neighbors. The reduction in regional tension has allowed the Govermnent to move away from management of a siege economy under an oil embargo, towards the implementation of a comprehensive stabilization and structural reform program. Recent Economic Developments 1.3. The hyperinflation and major fiscal deficit of 1993, resulting from massive net lending to enterprises and an inflow of rubles withdrawn from circulation elsewhere in the FSU, have been substantially eliminated with the help of currency reform and vigorous measures to bring inflation under control. Public expenditure has been limited to priority items and revenue collection increased, while interest rates on central bank refinancing of commercial bank credit have been allowed to become highly positive in real terms to further restrain monetary growth. Fiscal and monetary restraint was enhanced by abolition of the bread subsidy in 1995. The fiscal deficit declined from 48.2% of GDP in 1993 to 16.4% in 1994, and 8.7% in 1995. For 1996 it is projected to reach 8.2% of GDP. Inflation has fallen sharply, to 1.1% per month in October 1996 compared to 46% per month at its peak in 1994, prior to the stabilization program. This has been accompanied by broad stability in the nominal exchange rate since the Spring of 1994, which has enhanced confidence in the new currency.

The current account deficit and reserve accumulation have been financed primarily by IMF and concessional donor resources. Export trends are encouraging. 1995 exports of goods and factor services were 22% above those of 1994, (and 1996 exports are projected to be 16.5% above those of 1995). At the same time, export data show some diversification into non-traditional markets; 1995 exports to non-FSU countries were some 78% higher than in 1994 (from 3 1% of total exports to 46%) while exports to FSU countries fell by 7%. Future export growth is expected to come primarily from light industry and services and, to a lesser extent, from agroprocessing. The export improvement is supported by enterprise survey information, as is the recorded export diversification. In addition, foreign direct investment is beginning to pick up as privatization accelerates. However, these achievements in GDP growth and external adjustment remain fragile. Poverty has become pervasive in Armenia since 1991, particularly in urban areas. Recorded unemployment is 5% of the labor force but a further 15 to 30% are estimated to be on involuntary unpaid leave or reduced pay for shortened working hours. 1.6. The recovery of the Armenian economy will be sustainable only if it is accompanied by significant investment in productive capacity, infrastructure, and human resource development that is consistent with balance of payments viability and low inflation. From 1996 aggregate investment is expected to increase steadily as a percentage of GDP. Foreign private flows, whether through loans or direct investment, can be expected to become substantial once the economic recovery is more advanced, regional stability secured, and the financial sector more capable of playing an effective role in intermediating savings and investment. There are now the first indications of longer term investment
 interest from the Armenian Diaspora and other sources which the present project is designed to tap. Foreign investment increased from a minute $2.6 million in 1994 to $19.1 million in 1995 and is projected to rise in 1996 to $34.0 million, taking a steadily increasing share of overall investment. Stabilization and Structural Adjustment 1.7. The stabilization program was initiated in 1994, and a Systemic Transformation Facility (STF) was approved by the Fund in December 1994, followed in June 1995 by the approval of a Stand-By Arrangement (SBA). An Extended Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF), approved in February 1996, is intended to achieve greater integration of stabilization and structural reform policies over 1996-98. The structural reform program was initiated at independence. Prices of most goods and services were liberalized in January 1992. The collective farm system was quickly broken up and land was privatized to small holders (87% of agricultural land is now privately owned and available for sale). In parallel, privatization of small enterprises began: 335 enterprises, mainly shops, had been privatized by mid- 1992, although the legal basis for this was not yet fully developed. In January 1994, Parliament adopted a privatization program, which began to be implemented in the fall of 1994. Subsidies to enterprises and directed credit were both curtailed sharply during the year; and a liberal import regime was put in place. A Rehabilitation Credit was approved in February 1995 to support privatization, price liberalization and regulatory reform; enhanced financial discipline for enterprises and banks; and the social safety net. Implementation during 1995 was strong, with major achievements in the privatization of small-scale enterprises and of housing, the elimination of consumer subsidies, and establishment of a legal framework to support private sector development. As a result, a Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) was approved by the Board on February 28, 1996. Implementation of structural reforms under the SAC has continued to be strong. Major steps have been taken to tighten financial discipline, especially in the energy sector. This has been accompanied by accelerated progress in privatization and financial sector reform. The Project Background 1.8. The economic reform program supported by the Bank and Fund has made substantial progress in the establishment of a business environment supportive of enterprise, but the successful rehabilitation of the economy depends critically on institution building and new investment in productive assets. Up to now, the combination of domestic dissaving, macro-instability, and the blockade has effectively eliminated investment, other than that financed by humanitarian aid such as for earthquake rehabilitation. However, improvement in all the above areas has now started to attract foreign investors. In order to provide a catalyst to such investor interest, the proposed project is designed to provide assistance to strengthen the enterprise sector, financial institutions, and the client companies of the financial sector. Complementing institutional development, long-term financing is expected to be made available through the domestic banking system and through a specialized investment company. The proposed project will thereby build on the reforms launched under the Rehabilitation Credit and the SAC.
 II. THE FINANCIAL SECTOR The Current Situation in the Financial Sector 2.1. Structural Change. Since the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991, the Armenian financial sector has developed rapidly in terms of number of institutions. Through 1993, a liberal approach to new entry with very low minimum capital requirements resulted in the establishment of almost 60 new banks, some with significant foreign ownership stakes. Many banks have closed since March 1994, partly because of increases in minimum capital requirements, and the number now licensed by the CBA is 35, of which one is foreign owned. Fewer banks than at present would be likely to be operating in the future Armenian banking system. The new prudential regulations that have been already introduced will force at least five of the smallest banks toward mergers or liquidation. According to the CBA, for the moment seven "main" banks (excepting Midland-Armenia), including the four former State banks, account for 79% of total bank assets; the "medium" banks (twelve) account for 9.6%, and the small banks (15) account for 3.8%. The fifth bank which remains from the Soviet period - the Savings Bank - is small in asset terms but still accounts for the majority of the branch network. The Midland-Armenia bank opened in March 1996. The Midland, because of its superior capital and management practices, and clean portfolio, will become an early competitive threat to the longer-established banks. With the assistance of EU-TACIS in collaboration with Credit Agricole an Agricultural Cooperative Bank also opened in March 1996. 2.2. Money and Credit. The positive developments in the sector are still overshadowed by the problems of Armenia's fragile economic situation. From 1991 to early 1995, de-monetization of the economy occurred as the monetary holdings were either degraded by inflation or reduced as people moved savings into foreign currencies and other inflation hedges. This de-monetization was reflected in a decline in the broad money supply from over 100% to the equivalent of only 13% of GDP by 1994. The deposit component of total money declined from the equivalent of 98% of GDP in 1991 to only 7% of GDP by 1994. This decline in the volume of deposit resources available to banks, in tum, led to a serious drop in the supply of credit relative to real economic activity. Total bank credit outstanding fell from 67% of GDP in 1991 to less than 10% of GDP by 1993. Because of high inflation the limited credit available was lent on very short maturities - typically one to three months. The situation regarding the deposit and credit aggregates is shown in Figure 1. 2.3. Interest Rates. Interest rates (in dollars and Drans) moved strongly into positive territory during 1994 as a result of liberalization and monetary restraint. As the stabilization program has taken hold, nominal interest rates on both bank loans and bank deposits have since fallen significantly with the decline of inflation through 1995 and 1996. The 6-month dram lending rate declined from 24% per month in October 1994, to 6-9% during the early part of 1996. Dollar lending rates for 6-month loans declined from about 8% to 3% per month during the same period. This decline has been associated with a narrowing of bank margins when liquidity has been tight, with margins on 6-month business declining steadily over 1995-96.

The CBA has over the past three years made substantial progress in developing a sound system of regulation and supervision for the banks, governed by a CBA resolution of April 1995. Regulations have set minimum statutory capital levels, equity ratios, liquidity ratios, required reserves in the CBA, and loan exposure limits to single borrowers. Banks are also

It is estimated that by the end of 1996 more than half of all doubtful loans will have been provisioned. Loans are classified according to international standards, on the basis of their delinquency status, number of extensions, and collateral. A provisioning range in most cases allows discretion in recognizing risk. 2.6. Supervision of the banks is the responsibility of the departnent of bank supervision, regulation and licensing in the CBA. The department is also responsible for supervising other banking transactions such as the foreign exchange activities of nonbanking institutions. Licensing and Supervision departments have been combined, allowing information sharing between on-site and off-site supervision, and substantial progress has taken place on supervision programs, with the assistance of the IMF. 2.7. Until recently, banking law was inadequate in its definition of the powers of supervisors, sanctions and enforcement measures and the handling of failed banks. However, a new Banking Law which addresses these problems was passed by Parliament on June 30, 1996. Together with the parallel legal arrangements contained in the new law on the Central Bank itself and the new Law on Bank Insolvency, the authorities are now in a much stronger position to exert regulatory authority over the banking system. 2.8. The Role of the Proposed Project in Financial Sector Institution-Building and Reform 2.12. The challenge for banking reform programn is to establish a small group of stronger banks able both to mobilize savings and provide investment and other credits and financial services to local enterprises in the post-privatization era. The guiding principle of this reform strategy is that it should strengthen the best banks while those with little or no potential should be closed, merged or substantially restructured. Continuing regulatory reforms are also needed, especially in on-site bank supervision, although, as stated, considerable progress has been made. This will create pressure for better quality banking from above through the CBA, while individual banks are encouraged, inter alia through the proposed operation, to strengthen their own performance. On the basis of the audits it is expected that, in a number of banks, financial performance is adequate, and that capital positions and banking capacity would be strengthened further. This would take place with the help of a pilot loan work-out program under way for two of the larger banks under the SAC TA operation, and with broader institution building support under the proposed project, channeled through a banking advisory unit. 2.13. This operation would include a credit line which would provide an incentive to banks to upgrade their operations, while the accreditation conditions would ensure that banks that qualify will have the ability to make relatively sound credit decisions. Banks which have received positive audit reports will have access to early support from the technical assistance component of the project to achieve accreditation. The incentive of future access to the credit line should encourage other local banks to take advantage of the technical assistance support, which has been designed to provide both necessary up-front diagnostics and sustained support to banks through the proposed banking advisory unit. The results of the portfolio audits and other inspection visits suggest that early accreditation could be achieved by at least two commercial banks. Apart from support to the banks, the project would also strengthen the financial sector through capacity building and provision of a line of credit through an investment corporation (the PIFCA) designed to mobilize foreign investment for small to medium scale private enterprises. Both Yerevan Stock Exchange (YSE) and Gyumri Stock Exchange (GSE) are Self Regulating Organizations, and have their own internal regulations and listing requirements. In addition, there is a Yerevan Commodities exchange ("Adamand"). There are approximately 40 stockbrokers employed at the banks, about 17 individual broker seats at the YSE, and another 10-15 licensed brokerage companies. In addition, an investment fund has also been formed, managed by a licensed management firm. 2.15. The capital market is largely concerned at this stage with providing the infrastructure for the trading of privatization vouchers. A centralized share registry has been established and regulations were passed in April 1996. Companies are not, however, obliged to register centrally and few have so far, creating a potentially disorderly situation. There is no provision as yet for clearing and settlement, nor arrangements for linking a depository with registration. Regulation and licensing of privately owned share depositories is also expected to take place in 1996. Although the three stock and commodity exchanges are currently authorized to operate, only three companies (other than YSE's own shares) have yet been listed. 2.16. Once the share registry and depository are established, the next major requirement is the provision of regulations regarding market transactions. Though the stock exchanges have tried to set up temporary regulations for their members, these are not comprehensive and lack the force of law. A securities market supervision unit in the MOF (the SMS) presently licenses only brokerage firms, while individual brokers and managers of investment funds are licensed by a separate autonomous agency which, however, has no secretariat and no other regulatory responsibilities. There is a need for a single securities regulatory body with adequate resources, authority and responsibility to develop and administer the securities regulations in the country effectively. The commissioners should be drawn from state agencies (e.g. CBA), the stock exchanges, and other private intermediaries. 2.17. Trading and Transactions. The major impetus in secondary trading in equities is expected to come from the privatization process, whereby a number of private individuals now own shares in about 800 medium to large companies. Shares are increasingly in private hands, but the market is constrained, inter alia, by lack of information sources to facilitate trading. As a result, secondary trading will only emerge slowly. The only primary trading outside the mass privatization program up to now has been the public offer of shares in three banks. There is at present no trading in corporate loan or equity securities, and bonds are confined to Government issues. The CBA has been the primary dealer for these bonds and only banks could directly purchase them. The first Treasury bill auction took place in September 1995. 2.18. Commercial banks currently do not require special licenses to operate in the securities market, and are mainly regulated by the CBA. They are not allowed to borrow to purchase securities but can act as intermediaries or invest profits. However, they are active in trading in privatization vouchers, and, given the weak state of their balance sheets, there is a need for control over these trading activities. The law requires registration of all types of collateral with a local notary office or another authorized agency. Although the law establishes basic principles for using collateral in commercial transactions, it needs to be strengthened. Several provisions make general reference to other applicable legislation whereas, in order to promote lending, it would be preferable for this law to be self contained; i.e. it should specify completely the rights of the parties in secured transactions. Among its apparent deficiencies, the law fails to set up an efficient mechanism for foreclosure on and sale of the secured property. The aims and method of operation of the ESF will be set out in its operational manual. The ESF aims to enhance the competitiveness of private Armenian firms. The objectives are to assist actual and potential private Armenian exporters search for, enter, and maintain export markets and locate prospective joint-venture and contractual partners. The ESF is designed to overcome two key problems: (a) poor export market focus due to lack of market development strategies to develop existing and potential competitive advantages, and (b) inability to search out prospective foreign joint- venture partners who could provide managerial and technical know-how and access to international markets. The ESF would assist Armenian firms address these two problems by providing grant financing to firms to partially meet their costs of contracting specialized consulting services in: (i) export assistance, and (ii) interfirm matchmaking. Under normal circumstances, banks are reluctant to lend for exports since risks are greater in comparison to lending for domestic sales. This is particularly true for new exporters and start-ups. However, if the firm has gone through a systematic process of analyzing and developing its competitive potential and/or has alliances with successful foreign firms, then bank loans may be more forthcoming especially if banks have been involved in the support program. 4.13. The design of the proposed ESF is based on experience acquired from similar programs in other countries, including India and Kenya. Some of the key lessons have been that, because the needs and problems of each firm are unique and vary, enterprise support services must be tailored to the specific competitive circumstances of individual firms. Therefore, the support must focus on assisting firms to connect with and utilize experts who can provide the appropriate specialized services. Finally, strong ownership and commitment by firms is ensured if they share part of the costs of the program. Annex 2 provides a draft Statement of Policies and Operating Procedures for the ESF Program. 4.14. Fund Administration. The ESF would be located in the EDIPA. The EDIPA was established in December 1995 as an agency under the Ministry of Economy. It has no regulatory role and its mission is to provide fee-based advisory services to private Armenian enterprises and foreign investors. The ESF would be administered by an Executive Director with support from an internationally recruited Fund Manager. EDIPA would report to a Grant Approval Committee (GAC) to be established by the Ministry of Economy which would be responsible for approving grants in excess of US$ 25,000 and grants where the ESF cannot reach a decision (grant amounts below US$ 25,000 would normally be jointly approved by the Executive Director of EDIPA and the Fund Manager), and supervising the operations of the Fund. It marks the transition from the rehabilitation and macroeconomic adjustment phase of IDA support to Armenia, to intervention at the post-privatization and sectoral restructuring level. This operation focuses on the rationalization and recovery of production within the newly forming private sector by addressing key bottlenecks in enterprise financing, business skills and institutional development. 6.5. Policy Environment. Armenia is one of the most successful countries of the FSU in its macroeconomic stabilization program. Its budget deficit was reduced very substantially over 1994 to 1995, while the monthly inflation rate has fallen to a low level. Liberalization and stabilization of the domestic currency vis-a-vis the US dollar has started to stimulate capital inflows. Export taxes and quantitative import restrictions have been removed, and the maximum import tariff reduced to 10%. Price distortions have been largely eliminated. Interest rates are determined at auction and part of total credit is made available through CBA refinancing auctions to banks able to offer acceptable collateral. The remainder is offered at the auction-determined monthly interest rate, which has been positive in real terms for the past year. The interest rate on subsidiary loans under the project would be dollar- denominated and positive in real terms. 6.6. Core Economic Objective. The main objective of the project is to support a market-driven private sector investment and production response to the economic adjustment process. The resumption of economic growth in Armenia, the increase in capacity utilization, and the fast rate of privatization will create a good basis for the rapid growth of private business. The Project aims to start to mobilize external investment, which has been unavailable since the break up of the FSU, to stimulate the exports and foreign investment that are essential to economic recovery, and to mobilize local savings by strengthening the capacity of the banks and capital market.
 - 37 - 6.7. Achievement of Core Economic Objective. Technical assistance will address weaknesses in the banking system, such as portfolio management, credit management, and loan appraisal, thereby moving the financial reform process forward, and will build capacity in capital market institutions. The Project, combined with the perceived improvement in the economy and supported by the Bank/Fund dialogue, has already succeeded in mobilizing investor interest internationally and domestic enterprise and banking interest. By addressing key deficiencies in competencies of firms that impact on credit and project risks, the ESF will also improve the bankability of projects to be financed under the Line of Credit, through promoting international marketing, technological and trade contacts with Armenian companies. The provision of investment finance through the domestic banks and the PIFCA would provide the resources to fund the establishment, or expansion, of efficient private sector investment projects in a range of production and services, thereby financing growth of production. Finance will also create incentives for the strengthening of the banking system to mobilize savings for investment. 6.8. Institutional Capacity and Regulatory Framework. The Project will strengthen the capacity of an important and needed local institution - the EDIPA, which will coordinate enterprise-related foreign assistance in Armenia, and it will also establish a banking advisory service as part of a Bankers Training Center, which will provide assistance through training and consultancy to build capacity in the banks. The project will also assist the creation of an autonomous securities regulatory body and strengthen professional expertise in institutions such as the SMS, and will also strengthen the financial sector regulatory framework. 6.9. Fiscal Impact. The line of credit will provide budgetary resources to the Govermment through the spread between the cost of IDA (ITF) funds, and the onlending rate of the subsidiary loan (10 years at LIBOR plus 2%) from the Government to the participating financial institutions, less the cost of administering the PMU. Part of the spread to the Government should also be seen as coverage for its credit risk in the event of default by a PFI. The direct net budgetary benefit will depend on the rate of disbursement of the credit line. Based on a 7% net spread to Government, the present value at 10% of the net fiscal benefit accruing to the Government from the line of credit would be about US$2 million over the 6 year life of the credit line. The ESF consultancy funds, along with the funding of the associated administrative costs, are expected to be passed on a grant basis to the EDIPA. The Government would therefore bear a fiscal cost amounting to the cost of funds (0.75% per annum) and its own share of the operating cost of the EDIPA. This would be offset by the copayments by recipient banks averaging about 25% of costs. The net present worth of the net fiscal expense associated with the financial provision for the ESF would be about US$100,000. In the case of PIFCA institutional support, funds are expected to be onlent by the Government at IDA borrowing cost plus a margin for administration, with a zero net budgetary impact. Copayments for assistance from the BAU and the Business Adviser would result in a small net positive budgetary impact. 6.10. The positive direct fiscal impact would be enhanced by indirect fiscal benefits from the creation of new productive capacity. The technical assistance should therefore be seen as an investment yielding an enhanced stream of future fiscal inflows. The successful implementation of the line of credit and technical assistance will result in the broadening of the tax base through new businesses and employment. 6.11. Analysis of Alternatives. During project preparation, a number of alternative approaches were considered for the project. The main considerations were on the one hand the weakness of the financial sector and on the other hand the critical need for investment finance. The former suggested either waiting for additional reforms to take effect or focusing on a technical assistance operation alone to strengthen the banks and enterprise borrowers. However, the latter implied strongly the need to find a viable and effective channel to mobilize investment finance. Mobilization of investment through a guarantee operation was initially considered, but the progress of preparation of the PIFCA suggested that the PIFCA would be an appropriate alternative. The participation of the domestic banking sector has also now become feasible as a result of strengthening of the financial positions of several banks over
 - 38 - the past year, as shown through portfolio audits. Access to the line of credit is also expected to provide a strong incentive effect on the banks to fulfill accreditation criteria. The final design of the project combined institution building with a line of credit accessible to both the banks and the PIFCA. 6.12. Cost-benefit Analysis. There is little evidence currently of rates of return that are being achieved by long-term investors in Armenia. However, the credit demand study showed considerable interest from potential investors in borrowing at the rates for foreign currency loans which would prevail under the proposed credit (the subsidiary loan rate plus a margin of about 5%). Such enterprises would therefore be expecting financial rates of return of at least 15%. 6.13. Analysis of the sensitivity of the estimated rates of return to possible policy changes and sovereign risks can only be tentative. However, the continuing progress in improving the policy environment and implementing strict macroeconomic measures, and the growing geopolitical stabilization, strongly indicate that the number of opportunities for profitable business will grow. The proposed line of credit, which is modest in scale, can easily be topped up if it proves successful. 6.14. The residual effects of the blockade, especially on oil supply, would have the effect of increasing cross-border transport costs, thereby lowering real export FOB prices, and increasing import CIF prices. Thus the alleviation of the blockade will allow export prices to rise and import prices to fall. Economic analysis of subprojects would have to take account of these movements in estimating future border prices. Aside from this complication, the absence of major distortions, as described above, means that financial rates of return on subprojects would tend to reflect economic rates; and the stability of the reform process means that a divergence is relatively unlikely to occur in the future, so that financial rates of return will continue to approximate real rates. The Enterprise Support Fund faces three particular risks: (i) the environment may be constrained by underdeveloped legal and institutional structures that discourage foreign firms from entering into long-term relationships with Armenian firms; (ii) working capital and investment finance constraints may prevent firms from implementing export, import, or technological upgrading plans, and; (iii) EDIPA is a new institution with limited experience in delivering enterprise support services that are valued by firms. For the Banks and Capital Market, and for the Business Adviser, the main risk is failure to deliver effectively the know-how to the banks and securities agencies. The Line of Credit faces three main risks. These are: (i) risk of a deterioration of the political situation leading to an increase in cross-border trade disruption; (ii) bank systemic risk - the risk of bank failures or inability to achieve accreditation standards which prevents the credit being disbursed, and; (iii) risk of inadequate demand by eligible subborrowers or inadequate project preparation skills. The first of these risks is partly outside Armenia's control, but is mitigated because of the progress in international negotiations; the second is mitigated because of the tight control of the CBA, the support of the BAU, and the likely participation of the PIFCA, which would be well capitalized, managed by a reputable international investor, and is expected to be able to absorb a major part of the credit line. The third risk has been addressed through a credit demand study. Satisfactory demand for loans from viable borrowers at the terms and conditions offered has been projected over the next few years, and project preparation skills would be developed through the BAU, the Business Advisory Service, and a number of donor projects supporting enterprises. The aim of the Enterprise Support Fund (ESF) is to: (a) increase the competitiveness of Armenian exports and to assist actual and potential exporters to search, enter and maintain export markets and (b) assist enterprises to locate prospective joint-venture partners. The ESF will overcome two key constraints faced by enterprises: (a) poor market focus and lack of systematic export market development strategies that exploit the existing and potential comparative advantages of Armenian enterprises and (b) inability to tap into trade and investment networks. The specific objective of the ESF is to motivate and assist individual private Armenian firms in the preparation and implementation of cost-effective export expansion plans and in locating foreign joint-venture partners with the help of consultants specializing in marketing, design, packaging, quality, finance, engineering and investment brokering. A subsidiary objective of the ESF is to also strengthen local capabilities in delivery of specialized exporter support services. In order to achieve these objectives the ESF will provide grant assistance to Armenian enterprises to partially finance the cost of achieving the aforementioned objectives. Resources 2. Resources. During a three year commitment period, the ESF will be supplied with US$3.5 million (of which US$3.0 million will be for consulting services to firms) of IDA (ITT) funds to finance, on a matching-grant basis, eligible activities undertaken by private Armenian firms. US$0.5 million will be for the start-up and operating costs of the ESF. Total payments, including local payments and enterprise co-payments, will amount to a total of about US$ 4.55 million. Eligibility Criteria Eligible Firms 3. To be eligible Armenian firms must be in the private sector. A firm will deemed to be private if at least 51 percent of outstanding shares are held by private individuals or where management control is in private hands. In addition, privatized state-owned enterprises will also be eligible. All manufacturing, trading and service establishments that meet these definitions will be eligible. Eligible Sectors 4. Support under the ESF will be open generally to all sectors of the economy, subject to review.

Grant support will be given only for those target markets in which export sales are realized in convertible currencies. Priority will be given for export development plans aimed at industrialized markets. Export development and marketing activities aimed at protocol trade or barter transactions will not be eligible for support. 7. Eligible Activities. The aim of the ESF is to encourage a strategic perspective on export markets based on stable buyer-seller relationships. Such relationships are necessary for sustaining and increasing exports in the medium to long-term. Hence, under the ESF grant, fimance will be provided for all activities that prepare firms to enter into long-term buyer-seller links. However, working capital requirements will not be supported. Further, the ESF will not finance acquisition of plant and machinery with the exception of items such as minor tools, jigs and fixtures; testing and quality control equipment; blueprints and drawings; and office equipment. A number of market development activities can qualify for support. Ultimately, the Manager of the ESF, in conjunction with the fund manager, will have to make a judgment regarding the eligibility of any proposed activity. However, for the purposes of illustration and guidance a typical list of eligible activities would include the following: * Desk Research. This activity aims at assisting the firm in undertaking a preliminary analysis of most promising export prospects, internal capabilities of the firms, and analysis of competition. This activity is based on information available on site and may be undertaken in collaboration with the Fund Manager. The quality of desk research is often an important indicator of the firms willingness to enter export markets. This activity is the initial step in the development of an export marketing strategy. * Overseas Field Market Research. This activity provides the main inputs into the formulation of an export marketing strategy. It aims to answer basic questions relating to products, target markets, target buyers, buyer requirements, purchasing decisions, distribution channels, competition, and main factors effecting demand for the firm's products. Typically, this activity is undertaken in collaboration with consultants who have detailed knowledge about specific products and markets. * Minor Product Adaptation. This activity aims at making Armenian products more acceptable to overseas buyers. Under this activity support will be given for advisory and technical services relating to process, product and packaging redesign. * Overseas TraveL During the process of developing an export marketing strategy, company executives may need to travel abroad for identifying buyers and suppliers and for obtaining information about standards, distribution channels, competition and other market/buver specific information. If necessary, under the ESF, assistance will be provided for meeting the cost of such visits. * Product Certifi cation. In many cases, before placing orders overseas buyers will wish to establish the quality of the products or the manufacturing process. Buyers may also wish to ascertain in advance quality assurance procedures employed by Armenian firms. The Line of Credit will finance the following expenses, according to the specific disbursement guidelines set out under the project's Credit agreement: - expenditures in foreign exchange relating to the direct importation of equipment, including assembly, and goods on the basis of the CIF price of the respective bill; - expenditures due to procurement for construction and rehabilitation of factory buildings, warehouses and offices - procurement of goods and merchandise in the domestic market, and; - the cost of consultancy services relating to the subproject. IV. With regard to the methods of procurement of fixed assets and inventory, the PFI will be responsible for instructing the BE in order to ensure that such procurement will be carried out at the lowest cost and to obtain the best quality, according to the procurement guidelines established under the project. It will be the responsibility of the PMU to be present at the proceedings and to verify that these conditions are complied with. V. The following eligibility and evaluation criteria are hereby established:
 Annex 4 Page 3 of 5 - The PFI shall initiate evaluation of the financing requests relating to subprojects only if the requests and the respective BEs qualify under the definitions set out in the Subsidiary Loan Agreement. - On an exceptional basis, subprojects may be considered if they demonstrate a high economic/ financial profitability and if, in compliance with the financing objectives of the Credit, they do not significantly exceed the maximum amount referred to in the Subsidiary Loan Agreement. The PFI, in its report submitted to the PMIJ, must duly set forth the reasons that, in its opinion, may justify exceptional approval of the investment. Total value of approvals under this exception cannot exceed 25% of the total credit. - Only those investment subprojects that satisfy the following conditions will be submitted to the PMU: - the BE demonstrates adequate financial capacity to meet the liabilities already assumed as well as the liabilities arising from implementation of the subproject; and - the subproject does not involve unacceptable environmental costs. VI. The PFI will monitor and financially supervise the subprojects. It will be the responsibility of the PFI to carry out the following activities, among others: - Determine whether the funds were duly utilized and take any measures necessary to achieve this objective. - Monitor the financial status of the project, until the BE's obligations relating to the loans taken for financing the subproject have been fulfilled.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Enterprise Development Project for Armenia are to: a) assist in financing such productive facilities and resources as will contribute to the economic and social development of the country; b) strengthen commercial banks and other financial institutions and the capital market, and c) strengthen the investment and export market development capacity of private enterprise. The project will consist of assistance to project management through the project management unit (PMU), as well as the following components: a) institution building in enterprises, banks, and capital markets; and b) credit line component.
